intro: Fagara brachyacantha, commonly known as the short-stalked fagara, is a member of the Rutaceae family and is native to tropical regions of Central and South America. It is a small to medium-sized evergreen shrub or tree that typically grows in moist, shaded environments within tropical forests. The plant features compound leaves with elliptical leaflets and produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters. Its fruits are generally globose, berry-like structures that contain several seeds. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
